ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A fantastic course with a syllabus that you won't find anywhere else -- we talked about early recording techniques, experimental labels, sound art and more, with an emphasis on DIY approaches. Learned how to cut vinyls and dub cassettes. I appreciated the focus on the record as a wholistic product: we made not just the music, but also the packaging. The projects were great. I finished the course having made two conceptually interesting EPs - there's no other class at Yale where the output feels so ready for the real world.

Ableton/usage of DAWs, using audio cassettes, creating tape loops, using audio recording equipment, the vinyl lathe cutting process, creating physical packaging for sound mediums, creative usage of sound art, sound history
I learned how to use ableton with no previous musical experience.
Analog music-making

I learned lots about the history of recording and the music industry, through interesting lectures on topics such as sample culture and the impact and influence of different recording formats. The lectures were highly engaging and through class projects I felt like I had a chance to work in all the media we discussed and see first hand how it shaped the history of recorded sound.

I learned a lot about the history of sound and analog technology, and a bunch of stuff about conspiracy and other randomness that I didn't really care to learn. 
My engagement really varied by class. Some classes were very interesting and introduced me to a world that I knew nothing about, and other classes were rather painful with little awareness from the prof (never a single break during class of almost 2 hours) that he was just talking at us. 
Ultimately, you do cool projects and there is not another class like this at Yale, so I do recommend if sound is your cup of tea.

I learned a ton about older media & technologies, as well as interesting musical/visual art techniques. It was really cool to be able to physically create meaningful projects which we were super interested in.

Explored the physical media of sound and learned new techniques for creating and evaluating music/ sound. I learned to think of recording music as an art form in itself separate from the music itself.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Ross was amazing, topic choices were excellent. Grateful for all of my classmates as well, felt so good to be in such a rigorous group of artists.

Ross is extremely caring, passionate, and engaging. He clearly cares a lot about sound and his enthusiasm is infectious. He is also super understanding and willing to work with every individual student to address their specific needs. This course is also super interesting and unique!! There's nothing like it
I wish everything was more organized pertaining to class time but I still felt like I learned.
Ross is a great person, but I think he should have set clearer expectations for all the assignments.

This course is great! I love the format, lectures were always interesting and Ross is such a wealth of knowledge on everything he covers in class. I love how focused the class was on creating, as I feel the best way to learn about these topics is through experience.
This class was a great way to advance as an artist, as well as collaborate with and learn from other students/professor. I've never been more inspired to create art than when I took this class.

I think that this class was very engaging and the once a week structure allowed me to really look into what we were learning each week and get excited for each new class. I think the course material was very interesting and my only issue was that weekly lectures could be slightly more structured to drive home a certain point.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're an artist or musician, you have to take this class.

YES YES YES
this is the greatest course I've taken at Yale so far and has fundamentally changed the way I now approach course selection. The stuff you do in this course is super unique and I walked away with such a greater appreciation of sound as a medium and sound as an art form. This is one of the first "creative" classes I've taken at Yale and now I'm itching to take more.

I mean... you get to put music/sound on "vinyl" using Ross's lathe cutter... how cool is that?!??
Yes, very fun experience.
If you like super super super weird music

Absolutely! If you want to learn about the origins and reasons for the current experimental music and multimedia art scene as it relates to recorded sound, this is a great opportunity. It's also great write pieces and create physical versions of them that you'll get to keep forever.

Yes, definitely. The professor is very helpful, so even if you're not that familiar with a particular subject, he will help you. I was exposed to a lot of cool things that I'm not sure I would've known about if I hadn't taken this class.
Yes. Even if the student is not a music or music adjacent student, the class is very fun and engaging.
